**Turkey and Syria Move to Demarcate Maritime Borders in the Mediterranean**
Turkey has announced its intention to demarcate its maritime borders with Syria in the Mediterranean, which has sparked strong reactions from Greece and Cyprus, who consider the potential agreement to be illegal. Egypt has not yet taken a stance, amidst its rapprochement with Turkey. The conflict over energy resources in the Mediterranean is escalating due to estimates of vast amounts of gas and oil, prompting countries bordering the sea to intensify their efforts to explore these resources. The balance of power in the Mediterranean is shifting, with Syria entering the equation, following Turkey's announcement of its intention to demarcate its maritime borders with Syria in the Mediterranean, which would allow the two countries to determine their areas of influence for oil and gas exploration. The Mediterranean has been a stage for border disputes in recent years, with Arab and European countries, including Egypt and Greece, facing off against Turkey. However, Turkey surprised everyone by signing an agreement with Libya in 2019 to demarcate their maritime borders, which sparked outrage in Athens and European capitals, including Cairo. Turkey's announcement has caught everyone off guard this time from the east, with its intention to sign an agreement with Damascus. Turkish Transport and Infrastructure Minister Abdulkadir Uraloğlu announced that his country aims to demarcate its maritime borders with Syria in the Mediterranean after the formation of a permanent government in Damascus, stating that 'this agreement will allow the two countries to determine their areas of influence for oil and gas exploration.' Any future agreement in this field 'will be in line with international law.' The only official response to the Turkish announcement was from the Syrian Transport Minister, Bahaa al-Din Sharim, who said that 'demarcating borders is not within the competence of the current government.' The Egyptian position remains unclear, amidst its rapprochement with Turkey, while analysts say it will be more complex, especially in light of the gas crisis Egypt is experiencing. The Syrian government has not yet taken a stance on the Turkish proposal, but sources from the Syrian Transport Ministry told Al-Araby Al-Jadeed that the minister had confirmed that 'all investment contracts in Syrian ports will be reviewed by a committee of legal experts.' Economic experts and lawyers from Syria and Turkey agree that it is the right of both countries to demarcate their maritime borders, as long as it is done in accordance with international law and ensures the rights of both countries. However, the Turkish initiative has been met with skepticism by some, who argue that it is not the right time for such an agreement, especially given the existing investment contracts between Syria and other countries, including Iran and Russia. The dispute over maritime borders in the Mediterranean has been ongoing for years, with some countries, including Greece and Cyprus, calling for the application of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, while Turkey claims to be acting in accordance with international law. The convention, which was adopted in 1982, states that each country has a 'exclusive economic zone' of 200 nautical miles. However, in the case of the eastern Mediterranean, countries with shared maritime borders are those with shorter distances between them. Syria is not a signatory to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and has refused to demarcate its borders with Lebanon. After the Syrian war in 2011, Damascus was largely excluded from the equation, only to return to the scene after Turkey's invitation to negotiate. Turkish economic analyst Yusuf Kocabasoglu told Al-Araby Al-Jadeed that 'Turkey has the natural right to have agreements with countries bordering the Mediterranean, and Turkey has the longest coastline in the eastern Mediterranean, with a length of around 1,100 kilometers. After the discovery of vast amounts of gas and oil under the Mediterranean, all countries bordering the eastern Mediterranean have strategic plans to explore and invest in these resources, and therefore, issues of demarcating maritime borders between these countries are a top priority.' He added that 'there are attempts by some countries, including Greece, Cyprus, France, and Israel, to undermine Turkey's role or create problems during demarcation with Libya or while maintaining the rights of Cyprus.' He emphasized the importance of what Turkey is doing to accelerate what needs to be done from bilateral agreements with Syria, as both countries border the Mediterranean, and 'no country has the right to object to countries that are adjacent and neighboring, as it is a natural and sovereign right.' Turkey was excluded from two conferences held on the gas of the Mediterranean in Athens in 2017 and in Cairo in 2019, and 'what Turkey is doing in what is called the Blue Homeland is its right that it will not give up, and it will follow the path with Syria as it did with Libya in 2019 and will not pay attention to objections as long as it is acting in accordance with the law and in the context of common interests.' The Syrian Bar Association's President, Ghazwan Qar'afel, said that 'the upcoming negotiations between Syria and Turkey must start from the rights and good relations of the initial demarcation that must be later followed by international laws and principles of the United Nations, and an attempt to distance ourselves from what we see as conflicts and polarization between countries in the eastern Mediterranean, because the current conflict between countries in the eastern Mediterranean has historical, economic, and geographical reasons, but the political factor dominates the conflict, which takes the form of escalation and complexity before the confrontation by a little.' The conflict between countries bordering the Mediterranean has escalated, especially after Israel's ambitions and its conflict with the Palestinians, Lebanon, and the dispute over Cyprus's Greek and Turkish borders, and Turkey's exclusion from the gas of the Mediterranean forum.
